metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Huazhaizi station, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Huazhaizi station eddy covariance system (EC) in the midstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2021. The site (100.3201° E, 38.7659° N) was located in the Zhangye City in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1731 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'oasis–desert system' refer to in ecological studies?
Definition.Answer: An 'oasis–desert system' refers to the unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid regions that balances between oasis and desert areas. It plays a crucial role in maintaining ecological stability, supporting agricultural productivity, and influencing the carbon balance in these regions.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems compare to those used in traditional inland river basins in arid regions?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection in oasis–desert ecosystems involves long-term observations using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, complemented by hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations. This approach provides comprehensive datasets that include energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and auxiliary data like soil and vegetation parameters. In contrast, traditional inland river basins might rely more on periodic sampling and remote sensing observations, without necessarily incorporating the detailed, continuous measurements provided by these advanced systems.

Comparison.Question: How does the scope of datasets from oasis–desert ecosystems compare to those from other ecosystems in terms of the range of parameters measured and data availability?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets from oasis–desert ecosystems offer a comprehensive suite of parameters, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with hydrometeorological data, soil, and vegetation parameters. This contrasts with datasets from other ecosystems that might focus on a narrower range of measurements, such as only hydrological or atmospheric data, and may not provide the same level of integration across different environmental variables. Additionally, the availability of long-term data from oasis–desert ecosystems is significant for understanding ecological interactions, whereas other ecosystems might not have such extensive temporal coverage.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred from the data processing steps used for eddy covariance measurements in desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The methodologies inferred include the use of Eddypro software for data processing, which involves steps like removing outliers, performing delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction. Quality evaluation is based on atmospheric stability and turbulence characteristics, and there is a systematic approach to filter out erroneous data and data surrounding precipitation events.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges faced by inland river basins in arid regions influence data collection techniques for environmental monitoring?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges such as ecological degradation, the drying up of water bodies, and desertification require data collection techniques that can accurately capture long-term changes in hydrometeorological variables, vegetation, and soil parameters. Techniques must be robust against harsh environmental conditions and capable of providing comprehensive datasets that include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the significance of long-term observational datasets for understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are crucial for understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems, particularly in terms of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. They help elucidate the ecological stability and socio-economic development of oases, contribute to achieving carbon neutrality goals, and support sustainable development in arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is long-term observation critical for understanding oasis-desert interactions in arid and semiarid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observation is critical because it provides a comprehensive understanding of the dynamic processes involved in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges over time. This continuous data collection is essential for recognizing patterns, assessing the stability of oasis-desert systems, and supporting ecological security and sustainable development initiatives, especially in regions significantly affected by climatic changes and human activities.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing long-term observation datasets in understanding oasis–desert interactions within arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing long-term observation datasets can lead to a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas. This understanding is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases. Moreover, it supports the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis and contributes towards achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in data collection influence the accuracy and reliability of flux measurements in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in data collection provides detailed half-hourly turbulent flux data, which are crucial for accurate and reliable measurements of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. These systems enhance the capability to monitor and analyze the exchange processes in oasis–desert ecosystems, thus supporting long-term observations and improving the data's scientific value.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems to achieve sustainable oasis development, carbon peaking, and carbon neutrality, thereby supporting the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for half-hourly turbulent flux data collection in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for half-hourly turbulent flux data collection is important as it provides quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives are achieved by including a comprehensive suite of observational datasets from both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives achieved include providing a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is significant for maintaining ecological stability, supporting socioeconomic development, and addressing the environmental crises in inland river basins.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can eddy covariance systems be effectively utilized to collect high-frequency data for analyzing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Eddy covariance systems are used at sites like the Heihe River Basin to collect high-frequency data, such as 10Hz, which is then processed into 30-minute averages. These systems include instruments like the ultrasonic anemometer and CO2/H2O analyzer, positioned at specific heights and orientations to capture accurate flux measurements. Data processing involves steps like outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response adjustment, and density corrections to ensure data quality and reliability.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the conversion of high-frequency raw data into reliable 30-minute average datasets in arid and semi-arid region studies?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing involves using Eddypro software to handle raw 10Hz data, which includes steps such as outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density correction. Quality evaluation is also performed based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics.

Enablement.Question: How do long-term observational datasets enable a better understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term datasets provide continuous records of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, which are crucial for studying the interactions within oasis–desert systems. Such datasets help in recognizing patterns and changes over time, aiding in achieving sustainable development and ecological stability goals.

Enablement.Question: What role do environmental conditions play in enabling the collection of accurate hydrometeorological data in desert and oasis regions?
Enablement.Answer: Environmental conditions such as the stability of the atmosphere, the presence of natural vegetation, and soil moisture profiles influence the accuracy of hydrometeorological data. Instruments like automatic weather stations and eddy covariance systems are used to gather data under these varying conditions to ensure reliability.

Judgmental.Question: What are the main challenges associated with maintaining consistent data quality in long-term observational studies in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges in maintaining consistent data quality in long-term studies in arid regions include dealing with harsh environmental conditions that can affect instrument performance, ensuring comprehensive data coverage despite potential data loss due to technical issues, and addressing the degradation of ecological environments such as drying rivers, which can impact observational consistency.

Judgmental.Answer: The integration of hydrometeorological data can significantly enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems by providing essential context on variables like radiation, soil temperature, and moisture profiles. This comprehensive approach allows researchers to analyze interactions more effectively and supports the development of models that account for the dynamic and interrelated processes influencing these exchanges.

Solutions involve deploying robust automated weather stations and flux measurement devices, such as the eddy covariance system and scintillometer, to capture comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes along with hydrometeorological conditions, while ensuring long-term monitoring to understand ecosystem dynamics.
